author: By Stanley Reed
title: An Automaker Has a Stark Warning for the U.K. Car Industry
description: Stellantis said post-Brexit export rules and the lack of a domestic battery manufacturer could force it to close its plants in Britain.
content: A distress flare has gone up from the beleaguered British car manufacturing industry. Stellantis, the company behind brands like Peugeot, Fiat and Vauxhall vehicles, has warned a Parliamentary committee that automakers with plants in Britain will struggle to compete in coming years amid the switch to electric vehicles and new post-Brexit export requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and J. David Goodman
title: Texas Legislature Bans Transgender Medical Care for Children
description: Texas became the largest state to a pass a bill banning puberty blockers and hormone treatments. Gov. Greg Abbott was likely to sign it.
content: Over the opposition of Democrats and the loud protests at the Capitol this month, the Texas Legislature voted on Wednesday to approve a bill banning hormone and puberty blocking treatments, as well as surgeries for transgender children. The state is poised to become the largest state to ban transition medical care for minors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Why Is an M.V.P. Outfielder Playing Shortstop? Because He Can.
description: Mookie Betts, a star right fielder, has been pressed into service at a position he hadn’t played in nearly a decade. So far, so good.
content: LOS ANGELES — Mookie Betts was returning from paternity leave, his car was stuck in Chicago freeway gridlock for what seemed like an eternity and he arrived at Wrigley Field late for that night’s game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: It’s Not Your Imagination: First Class Is Getting Bigger
description: Aiming to boost revenue and cater to a rising number of passengers willing to pay for premium seats, airlines are reconfiguring cabins and flying larger planes.
content: Does it seem like that long walk back to economy class goes past more and more rows of cushy premium seats? You may be right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall D. Eliason
title: Why the Supreme Court Is Blind to Its Own Corruption
description: No wonder Justice Thomas apparently thought his behavior was no big deal.
content: The scandal surrounding Justice Clarence Thomas has further eroded the already record-low public confidence in the Supreme Court. If Chief Justice John Roberts wonders how such a thing could have happened, he might start looking for answers within the cloistered walls of his own courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal Withdraws From the French Open, Wants to Play One More Year
description: Nadal, the Spanish star, has battled a core muscle injury since January. He said that next season “probably is going to be my last year in the professional tour.”
content: Rafael Nadal, the 14-time French Open men’s singles champion, will not compete in this year’s edition of the event that has defined his career because of an injury that has sidelined him for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Preaching Tolerance Abroad, as Hatred Surges at Home
description: As a new U.S. envoy combating global antisemitism, Deborah Lipstadt first acknowledges America’s surge in hate crimes. She is also navigating a debate about the very definition of antisemitism.
content: A year ago, Deborah Lipstadt, newly confirmed as the U.S. special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism, attended a White House reception and reintroduced herself to President Biden as he passed by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: As Biden Weighs Paring Public Assistance in Debt Limit Talks, Liberals Balk
description: A G.O.P. demand to impose stricter work requirements on recipients of food stamps and other public benefits has drawn a Democratic backlash, underscoring the tricky politics at play in the negotiations.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s demand that any deal to raise the debt limit must include stricter work requirements for social safety net programs — and President Biden’s hints that he might be willing to accept such a bargain — has drawn a backlash from liberal Democrats in Congress, underscoring the tricky politics at play in bipartisan talks to avert a default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Master Gardener’ Review: Paul Schrader’s Solitary Man
description: The director’s latest movie completes a trilogy about men in search of grace in a brutal world — usually by way of women, but thankfully they are vivid, too.
content: Part of the kick of “Master Gardener” is that the writer-director Paul Schrader manages to pull off this improbable movie. It shouldn’t work and, even after seeing it twice, I don’t think that it entirely does, which only makes it more fascinating and strengthens its power. There’s much to admire about the movie’s tense dreaminess, its pulpy undertow and severe elegance, as well as the astonishing, awkward sincerity with which Schrader hurtles headlong at questions of love, hate, race and redemption in an unforgiving world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Dismisses Case on Pandemic-Era Immigration Measure
description: The justices acted after the Biden administration announced that the health emergency used to justify the measure, Title 42, was ending.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday dismissed an attempt by Republican-led states to maintain the pandemic-era immigration measure known as Title 42.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers
title: Another Side of the A.I. Boom: Detecting What A.I. Makes
description: More than a dozen companies have popped up to offer services aimed at identifying whether photos, text and videos are made by humans or machines.
content: Andrey Doronichev was alarmed last year when he saw a video on social media that appeared to show the president of Ukraine surrendering to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gary Prado Salmón, Bolivian Captor of Che Guevara, Dies at 84
description: An army captain, he led the operation that tracked down the Communist guerrilla who had helped lead the Cuban revolution and was trying to foment one in Bolivia.
content: Gen. Gary Prado Salmón, who as a Bolivian Army captain led the operation that captured the Argentine revolutionary Che Guevara, a critical ally of Fidel Castro’s in the Cuban revolution, in 1967, died on May 6 in a hospital in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Royal Paradox: Harry and Meghan Seek Both Privacy and Publicity
description: Their pursuit by paparazzi in New York shows that neither leaving Britain nor having a police escort shields them from unwanted attention.
content: When Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, decamped Britain for the United States in 2020, he portrayed it as an act of survival against a relentlessly intrusive British press. On Tuesday, after a chaotic encounter with photographers in New York City, Harry found the media glare can be just as intense in his adopted home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Larry Mahan, the Elvis of Rodeo, Is Dead at 79
description: His eight championships made him a legend to his fans. His mod style, swashbuckling lifestyle and flirtations with Hollywood made him a star.
content: Larry Mahan, an eight-time rodeo world champion and swashbuckling showman who was once called “rodeo’s first matinee idol,” and who brokered that reputation into side careers as a Hollywood actor, a country singer and a purveyor of must-have cowboy boots, died on May 7 at his home in Valley View, Texas. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Cyclone Aid Stalled in Myanmar: ‘I Just Hope We Get Help Before We Die’
description: Aid groups in the war-torn country say they are having trouble gaining access to areas affected by the storm without approval from the junta.
content: Four days after Cyclone Mocha made landfall in Myanmar, killing hundreds and devastating communities in its path, aid groups seeking to deliver humanitarian assistance remained stymied by the junta on Thursday as survivors faced growing threats of hunger and illness.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Some of the Books That Hernan Diaz Owns Surprise Even Him
description: “The other day I was shocked to discover that somehow I have amassed a rather robust collection of books about punk rock,” says the writer, whose novel “Trust,” now in paperback, won a 2023 Pulitzer Prize for fiction.
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Ukraine and China Will Dominate G7 Summit, but a New Threat Lurks: A.I.
description: The leaders are expected to hold their first talks on a common regulatory approach to generative artificial intelligence.
content: President Biden began his foreshortened Asia trip on Thursday in Hiroshima, a city that devotes itself to reminding the world of what happens when a brutal war escalates into a nuclear one. There he prepared for discussions with his closest allies on two crucial issues: how to better arm Ukraine as it enters its counteroffensive against the Russian invaders, and how to slow, or halt, the downward spiral in relations with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Lind
title: Japan Can’t Pass the Buck Anymore
description: Countering the threat from China will require Japan to get off the sidelines and share more of the military burden.
content: Ever since World War II ended, Japan has been passing the buck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: What Would Happen if the U.S. Defaulted on Its Debt
description: Investors, executives and economists are preparing contingency plans as they consider the turmoil that would result from a default in the $24 trillion U.S. Treasury market.
content: The U.S. debt limit has been reached and the Treasury Department is finding ways to save cash. After it runs out of maneuvers, what once seemed unfathomable could become reality: The United States defaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, Hamilton Heights and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
content: A two-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 600-square-foot apartment with an updated kitchen that has a breakfast bar, a walk-in closet in the primary bedroom, two closets in the second bedroom, a wood-burning fireplace, beamed ceilings, casement windows and through-the-wall heating and air-conditioning, on the fifth floor of a 13-story 1928 doorman building with a live-in superintendent, mail delivery service, bike and laundry rooms, basement storage and a roof deck. Niklas Hackstein, Compass, 718-666-1377; compass.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Meet the Woman Responsible for #AliyahCore
description: Aliyah Bah cultivated her quirky aesthetic — a hodgepodge of Y2K, alternative and harajuku style — and watched it take off online.
content: For Aliyah Bah, it always starts with a miniskirt. Then she throws on earmuffs — always earmuffs. In fact, the 20-year-old former college student (and TikTok phenomenon turned model) showed up to our interview over Zoom wearing pink star-shaped earmuffs that poked out of her chocolate brown hair, despite the temperature in Atlanta, where she lives, being above 80 degrees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: How Could a Secret Early Release From Prison End in a Manhunt?
description: After a judge in South Carolina signed an order releasing Jeriod Price, a convicted murderer, the State Supreme Court overruled it. But Mr. Price remains at large.
content: Jeriod Price had served more than half of a 35-year prison sentence for murdering another man at a nightclub in 2002. Then, last month, he became a fugitive. The authorities in South Carolina warned the public that he was dangerous and “could be anywhere in the world,” pleading for information that could aid their sudden, frantic search.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Robin Stein
title: Military Caught Airman Mishandling Secrets Before Arrest but Left Him in Job
description: A Justice Department filing urging that Airman Jack Teixeira be held without bail said his superiors had admonished him for taking notes and conducting deep-dive searches last fall.
content: Air Force officials caught Airman Jack Teixeira taking notes and conducting deep-dive searches for classified material months before he was charged with leaking a vast trove of government secrets, but did not remove him from his job, according to a Justice Department filing on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: As the U.S. Attends the G7, China Hosts a Summit of Its Own
description: Xi Jinping of China is meeting with leaders of five countries in Central Asia, a region crucial to his geopolitical ambitions.
content: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is kicking off a summit on Thursday that the country is heralding as a historic milestone, rolling out the red carpet for five Central Asian countries that are critical to China’s regional ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe
title: TikTok Users Sue Montana, Calling State Ban Unconstitutional
description: A spokeswoman for the state attorney general said that his office had “expected a legal challenge” and was “fully prepared to defend the law.”
content: A court battle over First Amendment rights kicked off in Montana on Thursday after a group of TikTok users challenged the state’s new TikTok ban, which is set to take effect Jan. 1 and is the first of its kind in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Jeffery C. Mays
title: As Crisis Grows, All of New York’s Migrant Plans Are Met With Outrage
description: First the city tried hotels, then tents, then a cruise ship terminal, then school gyms. As migrants have continued to cross the border, the mayor pleaded on Wednesday for understanding — and ideas.
content: Since tens of thousands of migrants began arriving in New York City last year, the administration of Mayor Eric Adams has searched for one place after another to house them: hotels, parking lots, a cruise ship terminal and a pair of giant tents on Randall’s Island among them. Almost every idea has caused an uproar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How Did This Pasta End Up in the Woods? Students Share Their Theories.
description: We invited teenagers to invent stories to explain hundreds of pounds of pasta that were discovered dumped by a creek in New Jersey.
content: Hundreds of pounds of pasta were recently found dumped in mounds along a creek in Old Bridge, N.J. The picture above shows some of the 25 feet of spaghetti, macaroni and alphabet shapes that were discovered. The Department of Public Works visited the site and found “what appeared to be 15 wheelbarrow loads of illegal dumped pasta” in a residential neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Singapore Hangs Man in Second Drug-Related Execution in Three Weeks
description: The man had been sentenced to death for possessing less than 3.5 pounds of cannabis, a punishment that human rights groups condemned as grossly excessive.
content: Singapore on Wednesday hanged a man for trafficking less than 3.5 pounds of marijuana, its second execution in three weeks for a crime that carries a much lighter sentence in most of the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Taking on the F.B.I., Trump Allies Single Out a Former Agent
description: As Republicans and right-wing news outlets try to paint the bureau as politically biased, powerful members of Congress have trained their sights on a little-known former F.B.I. agent.
content: Over 25 years as an F.B.I. agent, Timothy R. Thibault reeled in big names while investigating public corruption, sending two Democratic congressmen to prison and overseeing sensitive inquiries into the Clinton Foundation and the former governor of Virginia, Terry McAuliffe, another Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘White Building’ Review: Coming of Age in Cambodia
description: Kavich Neang’s lush feature tells a largely autobiographical tale of growing up in a building whose often painful history is a microcosm of his country’s.
content: The title of Kavich Neang’s richly observed feature, “White Building,” is, first of all, an exaggeration: The dilapidated apartment bloc it describes is so chipped and black with soot that it’s barely white; indeed, it is so falling apart that it’s barely a building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: New Cases of Chronic Pain Outnumber Those of Diabetes or Depression, Study Shows
description: Research from the N.I.H. illustrates how persistent and pervasive the condition is across the United States.
content: New cases of chronic pain occur more often in the United States than those of other chronic conditions, like diabetes, depression and high blood pressure, according to a study from the National Institutes of Health. The findings offer a large-scale confirmation of what previous research has shown: Chronic pain is staggeringly common in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a documentary about the Hillsong megachurch and a top-shelf drama that never got its due.
content: ‘XO, Kitty’When to watch: Now, on Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: I Made You Another Meal Plan
description: At the intersection of paneer, tofu and feta are delicious opportunities for clever swaps.
content: They say that necessity is the mother of invention, and when I think of necessity, mothers and invention, I think of my colleague Priya Krishna and her mother, Ritu. Years ago, after falling in love with spanakopita on a family trip to Greece, Ritu expertly swapped in feta while making saag paneer when she could not easily find the fresh Indian cheese in Dallas. That’s how the saag feta recipe in her and Priya’s cookbook, “Indian-ish,” was born.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Centuries-Old Mystery: Did This Elusive Viking City Exist?
description: Was a “medieval New York” called Jomsborg a literary fantasy or a historical reality? New archaeological discoveries may provide a clue.
content: After the local government decided to build an observation tower atop a sandy hill on Wolin, an island in the Baltic Sea, a Polish archaeologist was called in to check the site before construction and look for buried artifacts from the spot’s macabre past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: In Montana, Creators Await — and Dread — a TikTok Ban
description: Under a newly signed bill, the state is poised to become the first to ban TikTok. Influencers living there have a lot to lose.
content: Kylie Nelson wasn’t worried about a potential ban on TikTok when she first heard about it in the press several weeks ago. “I didn’t think it was going to be a thing,” said Ms. Nelson, a 30-year-old lifestyle creator in Billings, Mont., who specializes in midsize fashion content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian, Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Says Accounting Mistake Frees Up $3 Billion More for Ukraine
description: The Biden administration has been under bipartisan pressure to explain how it intended to continue sending weapons to Ukraine quickly without asking Congress for more money.
content: The Pentagon has significantly reduced its estimate of the value of weapons it has sent to Ukraine, freeing up at least $3 billion to keep Ukrainian troops supplied in their war against Russia over the next several months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Jynneos Vaccine Offers Protection Against Mpox, New Studies Confirm
description: But the vaccine isn’t a perfect shield, the research shows, and many questions remain unanswered, including how long protection lasts.
content: The Jynneos vaccine provides real-world protection against mpox, and two doses seem to be more effective than one, according to three new observational studies published on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: The Dawn of a New ‘Century’
description: Century 21 reopened in Lower Manhattan less than three years after closing all of its stores. For some, it had felt like an eternity.
content: About two hours after Century 21 reopened as Century 21 NYC in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday, the store’s point-of-sale system crashed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Decade That Cannot Be Deleted
description: China’s efforts to suppress the memory of the Cultural Revolution have intensified.
content: It would seem impossible to forget or minimize the Cultural Revolution in China, which lasted from 1966 to 1976, resulted in an estimated 1.6 million to two million deaths and scarred a generation and its descendants. The movement, which under Mao Zedong’s leadership sought to purge Chinese society of all remaining non-Communist elements, upended nearly every hallowed institution and custom. Teachers and schools long held in esteem were denounced. Books were burned and banned, museums ransacked, private art collections destroyed. Intellectuals were tortured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Sanctuary’ Review: Who’s the Boss?
description: A wealthy heir and his longtime employee vie for control over their uncommon relationship in this twisty duet.
content: If you’re someone who regularly bemoans the dearth of movies for adults, then take heart: “Sanctuary” is here for you. Shot almost entirely in a single location and in just 18 days, Zachary Wigon’s supremely confident second feature (after “The Heart Machine” in 2014) is a jet-black romantic comedy hidden inside a twisty psychosexual thriller. Or maybe it’s the other way around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Huntington, N.Y., and Glen Ridge, N.J.
content: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath house built in 1999, with a front porch, a two-story entry foyer, hardwood floors, a living room and den separated by French doors, an eat-in kitchen with an island, an en suite primary bedroom with a gas fireplace, a finished basement with nine-foot ceilings, a built-in barbecue and a wood-burning outdoor fireplace, on 1.35 acres. Melissa Stark, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 631-255-4471; danielgale.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Butterfly Vision’ Review: A Ukrainian Soldier’s Lonely Struggle
description: A traumatized woman returns home from eastern Ukraine after being held captive by Russian separatists.
content: In the relentlessly bleak military drama “Butterfly Vision,” Lilia (Rita Burkovska) is a Ukrainian drone pilot struggling to readjust to life on the home front after enduring months in captivity at the hands of Russian separatists in the Donbas region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Go Birding With The Times
description: Shifts in bird populations can be a sign of a changing climate. This summer, help scientists learn about the birds in your area.
content: Our understanding of birds has been profoundly shaped by the work of everyday people. After all, anyone can step outside and pay attention to an untamed world swooping above.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Come Out Fighting’ Review: The Battle of the Budget
description: A veteran cast attempts to fend off a deluge of clichés in this cheap-looking, pleasingly scrappy war film.
content: The microbudget war movie “Come Out Fighting” is so conspicuously cheap-looking that it could be initially mistaken for one of the direct-to-video mockbusters made by the somewhat infamous indie studio The Asylum — those thrifty, semi-plagiaristic exploitation flicks like “Ardennes Fury” or “Operation Dunkirk,” which have little to recommend them besides their zany, so-bad-it’s-almost-good zeal. But while it has a blatant shoestring sheen, “Come Out Fighting” isn’t arch or irony-laden; in fact, the tone is quite serious, albeit also seriously clichéd. Between the dogfights, ambushes, minefield maneuvers and flamethrower attacks — all of them realized with cut-rate visual effects — the film is contemplative and somber, pensively reflecting on such steadfast wartime themes as determination, valor and courage among men. Perhaps needless to say, the movie features no women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to ‘The Headlines’, a Short Show on the Day’s Biggest News
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Moon Garden’ Review: Malice in Wonderland
description: The director Ryan Stevens Harris brings a young girl’s subconscious to eerie life in this unnerving feature.
content: “Moon Garden” is a nightmare tour through a small child’s psyche that the filmmaker Ryan Stevens Harris could have staged as an escape room, or a haunted house, or a themed restaurant where his creepy puppets and bizarro performers would chatter their teeth at you while smashing plates. It feels as though he chose to make a movie simply because that’s the handiest way to get his ghastly creations seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Andy Warhol in Copyright Case
description: The justices considered whether the artist was free to use elements of a rock photographer’s portrait of the musician Prince.
content: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that Andy Warhol was not entitled to draw on a prominent photographer’s portrait of Prince for an image of the musician that his estate licensed to a magazine, limiting the scope of the fair-use defense to copyright infringement in the realm of visual art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘White Men Can’t Jump’ Review: Bouncing Off the Rim
description: Even the trash talk in a remake of the 1992 street ball comedy has no spark, despite the best efforts of Sinqua Walls and Jack Harlow.
content: The 1992 sports comedy “White Men Can’t Jump,” written and directed by Ron Shelton, was a cheeky, provocative film that took a raucously skewed view of race relations and street ball. It’s a well-liked film, but not so immortal that the prospect of a remake would inspire thoughts of sacrilege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Result of Getting Side-Swiped
description: In which David Distenfeld gives me a bad case of earworm.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: At Frieze New York 2023, One-Person Shows That Shine
description: Exciting work from emerging artists exploring environmental change, and proof that much of the most innovative work of the past half century has been by women.
content: At its debut in 2012, Frieze New York, a spinoff of Frieze in London, came off as an imperious enterprise. The fair commanded an island in the East River. Getting there could be difficult and expensive. And once there, negotiating the miles of pedestrian aisles formed by some 120 galleries made for a humbling degree of exertion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Walmart Raises Its Outlook as Shoppers Look for Bargains
description: The retailer reported revenue that beat expectations and said it expected net sales to rise 3.5 percent for the year.
content: Walmart, the largest retailer in the United States, raised its annual guidance on Thursday, a sign that it expects shoppers to continue to gravitate toward its value-oriented stores as they become more selective about their purchases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Introduces ChatGPT App for the iPhone
description: OpenAI is aiming to build on the popularity of its chatbot with a smartphone app that responds to voice prompts.
content: Since ChatGPT debuted in November, hundreds of millions of people have experimented with the online chatbot, which can answer questions, write poetry, draft emails and riff on almost any topic from inside a web browser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin F. Boehnke
title: The Increasingly Absurd Illogic of Workplace Drug Tests
description: Medical cannabis is legal in 38 states, and CBD is ubiquitous. It’s beyond time to end this pointless and often downright harmful practice.
content: The email from my new job was not the welcome I was anticipating. I would “be required to complete a drug test within 72 hours,” it said. “Please be sure to check your email for instructions.” It was August 2018, and I had just accepted an offer as a faculty member to develop a research program on, of all things, cannabis’s therapeutic effects on chronic pain. But in addition to being a cannabis researcher, I have fibromyalgia, and I had been using legal medical cannabis for nearly 10 years to help manage my symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Classic New York Building Celebrates Its 101st Birthday
description: Rosario Candela was the architect of 215 West 92nd Street. He went on to design many more quintessential New York buildings.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at a 101-year-old apartment building on the Upper West Side that is celebrating its link to a famous architect. We’ll also say goodbye to Pale Male, the red-tailed hawk who captured the city’s heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: A Band’s First U.S. Tour Starts With a Rite of Passage: Getting Robbed
description: Forests, an emo band from Singapore, ended its tour in New York in high spirits, two weeks after being robbed in California.
content: An international rock band’s first U.S. tour is a moment to be celebrated, a sign that years of hard work have paid off. But just a few days into their American debut, the members of Forests, an emo rock band from Singapore, endured another rite of passage for some musicians traveling the United States when they stopped for the night at a California hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: A Vigilant Steve McQueen, a Misguided Maïwenn and Other Cannes Scenes
description: “Occupied City,” a documentary from the “12 Years a Slave” filmmaker, proves ambitious. “Jeanne du Barry,” with Johnny Depp, was an unfortunate kickoff.
content: If you are ever at a festival that’s showing a new movie from the British director Steve McQueen and he happens to be in the theater and you’re tempted to look at your phone, don’t. There’s a chance that McQueen will get out of his seat, cross the aisle and persuade you to redirect your attention to the big screen, which is exactly what he did Wednesday at the Cannes Film Festival when a mystery offender (not me!) fired up a bright little screen during the premiere of his documentary, “Occupied City.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Sam Zell, 81, Tycoon Whose Big Newspaper Venture Went Bust, Dies
description: With a fortune made in real estate, he went into the media business in a landmark leveraged buyout of the Tribune Company in 2007. Bankruptcy ensued.
content: Sam Zell, the real estate tycoon who specialized in distressed assets and acquired The Chicago Tribune, The Los Angeles Times and other storied but troubled newspapers in a widely criticized leveraged buyout of the parent Tribune Company in 2007, died on Thursday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Ukraine is expected to dominate discussions at the G7 summit.

title: You Shared What You Love About California

content: For weeks, you have been writing to me about why you love California and what our state means to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: F.B.I. Revokes Security Clearances of 3 Agents Over Jan. 6 Issues
description: At least two of the three agents are scheduled to testify on Thursday to a House panel investigating what Republicans contend is the “weaponization” of federal agencies against conservatives.
content: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has revoked the security clearances of three agents who either took part in the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, or later expressed views about it that placed into question their “allegiance to the United States,” the bureau said on Wednesday in a letter to congressional investigators.

title: Elizabeth Holmes Must Report to Prison on May 30 and Pay Restitution

content: Elizabeth Holmes, the disgraced founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, who was convicted last year on charges that she defrauded investors of more than $100 million, has lost her latest bid to stay out of prison while she appeals her conviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Rising global temperatures.
content: Temperatures are likely to soar to record highs over the next five years, driven by human-caused warming and the El Niño climate pattern, World Meteorological Organization forecasters said. There is also a two-thirds chance that one of the next five years could be 1.5 degrees Celsius, or 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit, hotter than the 19th-century average, the organization reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian Talamantez Brolaski and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: wild and blue
description: A 21st-century troubadour’s lament, from the country musician and poet Julian Talamantez Brolaski.
content: In “wild and blue,” the country musician and poet Julian Talamantez Brolaski has written a 21st-century troubadour’s lament. The poem begins with light and wind — fixtures of poetry. There’s the lyric sweetness of herons and mountains. Even Chaucer’s zephyr shows up. At its midpoint, however, the poem turns. The sorry state of the poet is revealed. The wind won’t blow, or at least not yet. The poem ceases to fly: Instead it’s grounded in the dusty corner. The diction turns, too, from the poetical to the everyday, nearly antipoetical idioms of “crying my eyes out” and “it’s no picnic.” Sadness has done this, extracted the wildness from both the poet and the poet’s vocabulary. Then the kink in the light returns. (This poem was originally commissioned by United States Artists and the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation and appeared recently in a slightly different form in Shift Space.) Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Graduation Caps
description: What images, words, sayings or symbols would you put on your mortarboard to sum up your school career?
content: Are you graduating from high school this year? If so, will you be participating in the long tradition of decorating your graduation cap? What are you planning to include on it, and what do those things mean to you?
source.name: The New York Times

description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 18, 2023.

author: By Ken Belson
title: An N.F.L. Doctor Wants to Know Why Some Players Get C.T.E. and Others Don’t
description: The newly opened National Sports Brain Bank plans to study head trauma specific to athletes. Jerome Bettis has already pledged to donate his brain.
content: PITTSBURGH — Joseph Maroon, a neurosurgeon, began working for the Pittsburgh Steelers as a consulting doctor starting in 1977 and over 46 years has examined and treated stars from the notoriously hard-nosed dynasty, including the Hall of Famers Terry Bradshaw, Mean Joe Greene and Lynn Swann.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What 40-Somethings Should Know About Breast Cancer
description: An expert panel has recommended mammograms starting at age 40. Doctors weigh in on risk and prevention tactics for this age group.
content: Last week, a panel of U.S. health experts issued a striking update to their guidance on breast cancer screening, urging women who are at average risk for the disease to start getting mammograms every other year starting at age 40, rather than age 50.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Andrew Solomon’s review of the new Abraham Verghese novel, “The Covenant of Water,” is that rare creature, the ambivalent rave. On the one hand, Solomon seems vexed by Verghese’s decision to focus on unambiguously well-meaning characters rather than the darker antiheroes we tend to see in contemporary literature. On the other hand, he gobbled the book down and fell hard for those same characters along the way. The tension between those reactions leads Solomon to some interesting places in his review, as he muses on the nature of goodness and the place of sentiment in fiction:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Even as He’s Out, Rafael Nadal Will Always Be a Part of the French Open
description: Nadal’s reign in Paris — full of flexed biceps, forehand winners and underrated court craft — is one of the great achievements in any sport.
content: In case, in this distracted era, you only have time to read the first paragraph on your phone, here is the essential from Rafael Nadal: No French Open this year for the first time since 2004; no retirement just yet.

title: The G.O.P. Primary: ‘City on a Hill’ or ‘American Carnage’?
description: What the emerging field of candidates says about the future of the Republican Party.
content: It’s 77 weeks before Election Day and over half a dozen people have already thrown their hats into the G.O.P race. On our new podcast, “Matter of Opinion,” Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen take a tour of the 2024 Republican primary field to understand what it takes to survive in the present-day Republican ecosystem — and maybe even beat the Trump in the room.

content: For music fans who came of age after Napster but before Spotify — roughly the first decade of the 2000s — the internet could seem like a kind of enchanted forest. Each day delivered a new bounty for the music-hungry, copyright-resistant and broadband-equipped.

title: What Is the F-16 Fighter Jet and Why Does Ukraine Want It?

description: Also, Meta publicly released its latest A.I. technology.
content: As leaders of the world’s wealthiest large democracies gathered in Japan for the G7 summit, which begins today, China kicked off its own conference with the leaders of five Central Asian countries. The split-screen diplomacy comes as tensions rise between the West and China.

title: Paul Simon Confronts Death, Profoundly, on ‘Seven Psalms’
description: The 81-year-old songwriter ruminates on mortality, faith and meaning in an album that could be a farewell.
content: What do songwriters do when they feel death approaching? As time runs out, some choose to spend it by determinedly creating music to outlive them.

author: By Carina del Valle Schorske
title: I Had to Quit Therapy to Finally Be Ready for It
description: Giving up on psychoanalysis made it possible to imagine going back.
content: I came to therapy as most people do: in desperation. After a sexual assault triggered my latent depression, I dropped out of college a semester before graduating. Over the next year, I grappled my way to the diploma. I knew I wasn’t well, but I still wanted to exercise some agency in my choice of treatment: Psychoanalysis sounded smart, flattering my vanity, and the institutes had lower fees for patients willing to undergo what they called a “full analysis.” The phrase shares a certain boastful intensity with “full throttle” and “full frontal,” and the program — four sessions per week laid up on the couch — was indeed demanding. If I was going to admit I needed therapy, the most rigorous version was probably the best. So I signed up. Dr. S was beautiful, warm and almost confrontational in her candor. I felt an immediate attachment.

title: The 1-54 Art Fair Brings Africa and Its Diaspora Into the Global Mainstream
description: Talking with Touria El Glaoui, its founder, about making a real difference in the careers of African artists.
content: Touria El Glaoui is the founding director of the 1-54 Contemporary African Art Fair, which is held every year in London, New York City and Marrakesh. The daughter of a Moroccan artist father and a French mother, El Glaoui was working in telecommunication sales when she founded the fair to give voice to art and artists from the continent and the diaspora, and it remains among the most important on the contemporary scene, introducing talents such as Amadou Sanogo, of Mali, and Johanna Mirabel, of Paris.

title: The Earthquake Changed Turkey, but Change Is Complicated
description: When life is still a question of today, not tomorrow, a vote for change can feel like a big gamble.
content: ADIYAMAN, Turkey — Adiyaman is a southern province of Turkey that a lot of people miss on a map. Too small, too poor, too pious. Too Kurdish, yet not Kurdish enough. Its neighboring provinces carry the weight of history; Adiyaman is mostly known for its loose tobacco.

title: How Well Do You Sleep at Night?

content: Do you sleep well at night? Or do you often toss and turn awake in bed, unable to settle into deep sleep? Do you usually wake up in the morning feeling well-rested, or do you find yourself tired and sleepy throughout the day?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lawmakers Consider More Security for Offices Following Connolly Staff Attack
description: After a man asking for Representative Gerald E. Connolly attacked two aides in his district office in Virginia, members of Congress and their staffs are exploring stepped-up safety measures.
content: The attack on two congressional aides this week at the Fairfax, Va., office of Representative Gerald E. Connolly has prompted members of Congress and their staffs to consider additional safety measures in their workplaces outside of Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim and Raja Abdulrahim
title: The Long Isolation of Syria’s al-Assad Is Over
description: President Bashar al-Assad was shunned over atrocities committed in Syria’s civil war, but on Friday he is expected to join an annual summit of Arab leaders for the first time in 13 years.
content: When a devastating earthquake struck in February, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria spotted opportunity in disaster. He called for an end to international sanctions on his country and within days, some were suspended. Other Middle Eastern states sent planeloads of aid and senior officials from those countries soon followed for the first high-level visits in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Nicholas Nehamas
title: ‘Biden and Me’: DeSantis Privately Tells Donors Trump Can’t Win
description: In a phone call with top donors, the Florida governor took his most direct shots yet at Donald Trump. He is expected to officially enter the presidential race next week.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida all but declared his presidential candidacy on Thursday afternoon, telling donors and supporters on a call that only three “credible” candidates were in the race and that only he would be able to win both the Republican primary and the general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Deutsche Bank Will Pay $75 Million to Victims of Jeffrey Epstein
description: A proposed court settlement closes another chapter in the German bank’s relationship with the disgraced financier, which began in 2013 and continued up until late 2018.
content: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay $75 million to sexual abuse victims of Jeffrey Epstein to settle a lawsuit filed last year in Manhattan, according to the lawyers for the victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Kia and Hyundai to Pay $200 Million to Settle Suit Over Car Thefts
description: The agreement in the class-action suit, which awaits a judge’s approval, would affect the owners of about nine million vehicles. It came as the nation contends with a surge in auto thefts.
content: Kia and Hyundai have agreed to pay about $200 million to settle a class-action lawsuit accusing the manufacturers of producing vehicles that have been especially vulnerable to theft, lawyers for the car owners and the manufacturers said on Thursday.

author: By Cade Metz and Mike Isaac
title: In Battle Over A.I., Meta Decides to Give Away Its Crown Jewels
description: The tech giant has publicly released its latest A.I. technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like Google say that approach can be dangerous.
content: In February, Meta made an unusual move in the rapidly evolving world of artificial intelligence: It decided to give away its A.I. crown jewels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
title: Israelis March Through Jerusalem, Raising Tensions in a Divided City
description: The annual parade marks the unification of the city after Israel captured East Jerusalem in 1967. Israelis see it as a celebration, but Palestinians consider it an insult, and it was marred by incitement against Arabs.
content: Thousands of Israelis marched through Jerusalem on Thursday to celebrate Israel’s capture of East Jerusalem in 1967, a contentious annual event, known as Jerusalem Day, that regularly stirs tensions with Palestinians, who see it as a provocation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Dodgers Face Backlash After Rescinding Pride Night Invitation
description: Saying they did not want to “distract” from the event, the Dodgers announced that the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence would not attend. Now other groups are pulling out.
content: The Los Angeles Dodgers are facing criticism ahead of their upcoming LGBTQ+ Pride Night for the team’s decision to disinvite a group from what is scheduled to be their 10th annual celebration of diversity and inclusion on June 16 at Dodger Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘The Taking’ Review: This Land Is Not Your Land
description: Monument Valley embodies the Old West. But the fantasies presented in Westerns obscure its darker history and the lives of the Navajo people who inhabit it.
content: Whether it’s John Wayne films or Chevrolet ads, Monument Valley has been immortalized in the American imagination as a symbol of this nation’s vast potential. “The Taking,” a new documentary directed by Alexandre O. Philippe, examines the site’s complicated position as a representation of the Old West despite being located on Navajo land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen and Justin Porter
title: Meta Gave Away Its A.I. Crown Jewels
description: Also, the Supreme Court ruled against Andy Warhol. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: The tech industry’s race to develop artificial intelligence has been upended by a decision to give away a powerful system for free. In February Meta released LLaMA, an A.I. technology similar to the one powering ChatGPT, as open-source software that anyone can use to build their own chatbot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why the Catwalk Is Coming to Cannes
description: The next Indiana Jones movie isn’t the only big premiere at the Cannes Film Festival. Chopard is unveiling a full couture line, and Versace is showing a Dua Lipa collaboration.
content: The Cannes Film Festival, which began on May 16 and runs through the 27th, has always turned the Croisette into something of a catwalk, ever since Elizabeth Taylor arrived in her tiara back in 1957. The red carpet premieres and seaside photo ops offer such a bounty of style statements that it’s hard to believe the festival hasn’t been crowned an honorary fashion week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Battered by War, Sudan Faces Many Possible Paths — None Good
description: As American-led peace efforts flounder, experts warn that Sudan risks spiraling into a state of anarchy akin to its most chaotic neighbors.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The fighting that erupted in Sudan’s capital one month ago surprised few, the culmination of soaring tensions between rival military leaders. But what has shocked many is the scale and ferocity of the war engulfing Africa’s third-largest country, a conflict that has killed about 1,000 people and prompted one million more to flee their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tell us about your birding experience
description: Connect with other participants in the comments section here.
content: We’re so glad you’re taking part in our summer birding project! Tell us in the comments what got you interested in birding. And if you are just getting started, let us know what you could use help with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: South Carolina House Passes Six-Week Abortion Ban
description: The approval brings both chambers of the legislature closer to agreement on a ban after months of debate.
content: The South Carolina House of Representatives approved a ban on most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy on Tuesday night, setting up a repeat fight in a red state that has become an unexpected battleground over abortion. The vote came after roughly 24 hours of often rancorous debate in a rare special session called by the governor, and fell largely along party lines, 82 to 33.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Night of the 12th’ Review: When a Case Doesn’t Close
description: This refreshingly grounded French crime procedural portrays what happens when a brutal murder case eludes the diligent efforts of a by-the-book investigator.
content: Police procedurals don’t usually start by saying that the crime at hand will not be solved. But Dominik Moll’s “The Night of the 12th” does just that, and then watches a French investigator labor away at a murder case before reluctantly abandoning it. This is a refreshingly grounded, deceptively plain picture of crime-fighting as a grind of false leads, workplace fatigue and no closure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Nguyen, Rikki Novetsky, Ben Calhoun, Paige Cowett, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: An Anonymous #MeToo Source Goes Public
description: Ali Diercks, who was crucial to a major #MeToo story involving the CBS executive Les Moonves, talks about why she started sharing information.
content: This episode contains descriptions of alleged sexual assault.

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Judge Rules for Tiger Woods in Secrecy Battle With Former Girlfriend
description: The dispute in a Florida court focused on whether Erica Herman’s claims against the golf star could be heard publicly or only through arbitration.
content: A dispute between the golf star Tiger Woods and a former girlfriend about her right to live in his home must be resolved through arbitration, a Florida judge ruled on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Museum of the Revolution’ Review: Sheltering in an Abandoned Utopia
description: This quiet documentary observes three unhoused women from different generations who live among the remains of an unfinished museum in Belgrade.
content: Srdan Keca’s quiet observational documentary “Museum of the Revolution” is set in the purlieus of a onetime utopian building project: a monument to Yugoslavia that was meant to serve as a socialist gathering space. The structure was abandoned in the late 1970s, and today its unfinished basement level has become the dwelling place for a small community of unhoused people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Cade Metz
title: Twitter Accuses Microsoft of Improperly Using Its Data
description: In a letter to Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, Twitter said the tech giant had violated a data agreement.
content: Twitter on Thursday sent a letter to Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, accusing the tech giant of improperly using the social media company’s data.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Will the U.S. Run Out of Cash? The Answer Is Complicated.
description: The federal government is essentially living paycheck to paycheck, making the X-date hard to pin down.
content: In letters to Congress and warnings to business leaders about the catastrophic consequences if the United States defaults on its debt, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen has repeatedly offered an important caveat.

title: Review: Gibney Mines a Too-Familiar Contemporary Dance Mode
description: With a premiere by Tiffany Tregarthen and David Raymond at the Joyce, Gibney Company builds on its repertoire but doesn’t enhance it.
content: A performance by Gibney Company begs a question: What about this reinvented company does the dance world need? In 2023, what does it nourish? I’m still not sure.

title: Corporate America Faces a Bankruptcy Boom

content: First, corporate America was hit hard by a wave of layoffs. Now come the bankruptcies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Is the Latest in a Line of Politically Problematic Tech Bros
description: As political figures, they’re not innovating. They’re peddling ahistoric drivel.
content: Here’s a question that vexes me: Why does it seem that so many men who have been successful in the tech sphere and then waded into politics prove so problematic on issues of diversity and equity?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Hawaiian Bungalow Resort Reopens on the Big Island
description: Plus: playful lamps, Loewe Craft Prize finalists on view in Queens and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: In 2016, the Loewe creative director Jonathan Anderson initiated the Loewe Craft Prize, an open call competition for artisans and makers to submit one-of-a-kind works in the applied arts, awarding 50,000 euros to its winner. To announce the recipient of this year’s prize, the Spanish fashion house’s Loewe Foundation hosted a ceremony at the Noguchi Museum in Long Island City, Queens, on May 16. The jury consisted of experts in the field of design, including the ceramist Magdalene Odundo; Abraham Thomas, the curator of modern architecture, design and decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; and last year’s winner, the fiber artist Dahye Jeong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: For a Reporter, Opportunity, or Its Absence, Is Everywhere
description: Talmon Joseph Smith, an economics reporter at The New York Times, is charting the greatest transfer of wealth in U.S. history.
content: This week, The New York Times reported that the greatest wealth transfer in U.S. history, from baby boomers to their children and other heirs, is well underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Ferocious Oak Hill Daunts P.G.A. Championship Field, With More to Come
description: Birdies were at a premium for many of the 156 golfers vying for the Wanamaker Trophy at Oak Hill Country Club during the first round of the major tournament on Thursday.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Scottie Scheffler had, at least in the moment, a share of the P.G.A. Championship lead when he offered a foreboding prediction Thursday afternoon: Oak Hill Country Club, already playing to the point of menace in the first round, would only become more terrorizing.

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: To Fight Rats, N.Y.C. Restaurants Will Have to Put Trash in Containers
description: The move, which would affect 40,000 food-related businesses in New York City, would mean the end of piles of black plastic bags at curbside.
content: In the latest front in New York City’s fight against the proliferation of trash and rats, city officials plan to require restaurants and bodegas to set out trash in containers instead of bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau Rediscovers His Groove at the P.G.A. Championship
description: It’s only one round, but DeChambeau, the once hard-swinging golfer who has struggled of late, shot a four-under-par 66 at Oak Hill Country Club.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Bryson DeChambeau walked onto his final green in the first round of the 2023 P.G.A. Championship on Thursday and the modest gallery awaiting him remained hushed. DeChambeau was leading the event and on his way to a sterling 18-hole score, his best at an American major championship in three years. And yet, the roughly 200 silent fans near the green stared at him as they would an exhibit in a museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Weed Wine Is an Underground Favorite. Can It Survive the Gummy Era?
description: It’s delicious, but prohibited commercially, even where cannabis is legal. That hasn’t stopped winemakers from sharing recipes.
content: The pale ruby wine emerged from the bottle with a tinge of orange. It smelled lightly smoky, not as fruity as a grenache ordinarily might but unusually herbal. The aroma would have been right at home at rock concerts and college dorms of a certain era. On the palate, it was beautifully balanced with a lingering aftertaste. It was delicious. It was also illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Another Casualty in Ukraine: Teenage Years
description: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
content: The yawning crater, carved by a Russian missile strike and flooded with water, cut a jagged path through the middle of a city street. The small clique of teenagers passing by found it funny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: I Just Arrived in Kyiv. The Ukrainian Valor Is Breathtaking.
description: The combined power of Ukrainian valor and American technology may be even greater than we recognize.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — This week, I was jolted awake by an air raid siren for the first time since my service in Iraq just over a decade ago. It was roughly 3 a.m. on Monday night, and I was sleeping soundly here in Ukraine’s capital. I’m visiting with a group organized by the Renew Democracy Initiative, a pro-democracy organization founded by the Russian dissident (and chess grandmaster) Garry Kasparov, and our small band was of course warned this was likely to happen. Missile and drone attacks are common in Kyiv. But this night was different. Ukrainian officials called it “exceptional.”
source.name: The New York Times

content: When asked in a Senate hearing this week who was to blame for the demise of Silicon Valley Bank, the lender’s former chief executive, Greg Becker, had plenty of ideas, blaming regulators, the bank’s board and its own customers for bringing it down.

content: If there’s new hope, it’s blurry. What’s certain: The roller coaster tale of the ivory-billed woodpecker, a majestic bird whose presumed extinction has been punctuated by a series of contested rediscoveries, is going strong.

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘The Cow Who Sang a Song Into the Future’ Review: Mother Resurrected
description: This lyrical debut feature from Francisca Alegría is a slow-burning parable about our relationship to each other and to the living world.
content: The final 20 minutes or so of “The Cow Who Sang a Song Into the Future,” the slow-burning parable from the writer-director Francisca Alegría, are almost entirely wordless. In its last act, the film follows the members of a fractured family as they wander about, cast in different directions and undone by recent oddities on their dairy farm. The power of Alegría’s feature debut is found not in dialogue or explication, but in the lyrical, magical realist qualities of folklore: disappointed mothers and fathers, sacred animals and cursed rivers, love and forgiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Fast X’ Review: Drivers Wanted. Again.
description: Twenty-two years and nine sequels in, the “Fast and Furious” franchise is finding it hard to keep the thrill alive.
content: So much has gone over the top in these “Fast and Furious” movies — stunt work and demolition, obviously; but also family trees, racing, race, plots, pates, biceps, upper backs — that it wasn’t until I saw what Jason Momoa was up to in this new installment, “Fast X,” that I realized how much the acting had stayed under the table. He swoops in to play a flamboyant terrorist named Dante Reyes. And it’s pretty clear, from the pitiful quips he’s been given and the light-loafer treatment he’s going for, that the mustache Momoa’s twirling isn’t his. It’s Rip Taylor’s.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Ukraine’s air defenses shot down dozens of Russian missiles in the skies above Kyiv early Thursday, casting flaming debris over the Ukrainian capital on the same day that an explosion derailed a Russian freight train in Crimea, the latest in a series of blasts in Russian-occupied territory.

content: For more than two weeks, search-and-rescue teams in Colombia have scoured the Amazon rainforest for four children who were aboard a plane that crashed on May 1. The bodies of the three adults on board were found in the wreckage, but there was no sign of the children.

description: What do these memoirs have in common? They contain subtle lessons in persistence, coping and, yes, cleanliness.
content: Cassandra Jackson was in her 30s when she first encountered the expression “replacement child,” and it took her breath away. Coined by psychologists in the ’60s to describe a son or daughter conceived to fill the void after another child’s death, “the term is the closest I will come,” Jackson writes in her anguished, affecting memoir, THE WRECK: A Daughter’s Memoir of Becoming a Mother (Viking, 307 pp., $28), “to a name for what I am.”

title: Black Men Don’t Do Therapy. Or So I Thought.
description: What used to seem like an admission of defeat became a source of strength.
content: In 10th grade, a Jewish kid who had just gained admission to the high school I attended — a magnet school established to combat racial segregation by admitting students from across Los Angeles — showed up in my Japanese class. We were a cadre of Korean, Black and Latino kids who had been drawn to the class by curiosity about Japanese culture, and the sudden presence of a white student in the middle of the semester piqued our interest. In skinny jeans and sleek glasses, he reminded me of Rivers Cuomo; we became fast friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Stay Awake’ Review: Becoming Their Mother’s Caretakers
description: This story of a small-town family impacted by addiction succeeds in humanizing its characters but falters when it tries to include a coming-of-age tale.
content: Jamie Sisley’s narrative feature directorial debut, “Stay Awake,” is not a novel story for those with a family member or loved one struggling with addiction. A small-town drama, the film stars Wyatt Oleff and Fin Argus as two teenage brothers, Ethan and Derek, who are forced to become caregivers for their mother, Michelle (Chrissy Metz), after she becomes dependent on prescription painkillers. It’s an all-too-familiar scenario across the United States, and the highs, lows and disappointments that Michelle and her sons face throughout her rocky treatment are both incredibly human and unfortunately predictable.
source.name: The New York Times
